{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3567990,"name":"","username":"Matheus","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/ecd19e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T14:19:17.062Z","cooked":"

Hello everyone, my team uses an elevator system.

To define its positions at each level, we use the Neo’s own encoder. The software says that it always stops precisely, but in the real model it always varies a lot. When we evaluated the logs, we came across two messages that made us think a lot about whether this could be what is affecting us:

**
CAN message is stale, data is valid but old. Check the CAN bus wiring, CAN bus utilization, and power to the device.

**

**
CAN frame not received/too-stale. Check the CAN bus wiring, CAN bus utilization, and power to the device.

**

Can anyone tell me if this is actually affecting the elevator’s real position?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-25T14:19:17.062Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":254,"readers_count":253,"score":150.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496855,"topic_slug":"elevator-problem","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64053,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-problem/496855/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3567996,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T14:29:49.082Z","cooked":"

I would log your PID Error. That’ll let you know if the system thinks it’s at the right place, or if it knows it’s not

If there is PID Error, simply re-tuning your PID could solve the issue. We also added CF springs to ours to help pull up the elevator, which helped with speed and precision.

If there is no PID error, check for slippage in the drive system. We have a belt reduction from motor → Elevator, so if that were to slip, we would lose position.

Also check to make sure you have the a key in your motor shaft

I doubt that a few stale/dropped CAN frames is affecting position.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-25T14:38:39.346Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":229,"readers_count":228,"score":60.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496855,"topic_slug":"elevator-problem","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-problem/496855/2","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3568025,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T15:06:58.083Z","cooked":"
Chadfrom7226:

If there is PID Error, simply re-tuning your PID could solve the issue. We also added CF springs to ours to help pull up the elevator, which helped with speed and precision.

To add to this, the important thing to keep in mind is that your elevator has mass, and depending on how you built it, that mass could be significant, especially if you’re trying to move it at high speed and then get it to stop in a specific place. PID tuning can help a lot, but sometimes you also have to make mechanical changes.

For instance, the first version of our elevator was a continuous cable-driven configuration up with no pull down (due to tensioning issues). As a result, if it moved too fast, the elevator would effectively “jump” past the point the cable stopped moving. I’ve also seen elevators that have chain-driven first stages but cascading cable-driven second stages have similar issues.

Our solution was to convert our elevator to a continuous chain drive that worked in both directions and allows for more precise control. Not saying you necessarily need to do this, but as Chad said, Constant Force springs or some other solution might be needed to get the level of control you want.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-25T15:06:58.083Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":170,"readers_count":169,"score":49.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496855,"topic_slug":"elevator-problem","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/elevator-problem/496855/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3568113,"name":"Emre ","username":"DukeEmree","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dukeemree/{size}/251833_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T16:17:42.667Z","cooked":"
Matheus:

CAN message is stale, data is valid but old. Check the CAN bus wiring, CAN bus utilization, and power to the device.

It said the same thing to us, but it did not have any effect on the robot.

If you are using a rope in your elevator, your problem may be related to the rope winding. As far as I know, there may be slight differences in positions when starting to wind.

If the encoder reading is consistent but the real world position is not, then you have a mechanical problem between the encoder and the elevator carriage.

How much backlash is there in your system?
